body:
Hello.
I don't know if this the right place to put this problem.
But because it can be some bug I decided to put it in here.

I will try to describe this problem in detail.

I am a regular user and I have 3 full nodes running in my LAN at home.
And this nodes were running until a while ago without any problems.

I am using bitcoin 0.16.0 on all of them.

 I will call this machine node 1. This is my main node that is always running and it runs 24/7.
The hardware is dual core x64 with 4GB of ram. And the OS is Slackware Linux 14.2 64 bits.
This is the [`~/.bitcoin/bitcoin.conf`]( https://pastebin.com/tLEdfjyL) on it.

This node runs without any problem. I have port 8333 forwarding on my router for this machine.
I run it like this
```
bitcoind -daemon -disablewallet
```
I don't use X on that machine.

My goal with this node is to support the network and also the tor network.
At least it was the idea that I get from this guide

https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Setting_up_a_Tor_hidden_service

I am using the method 2 that says,

> If you don't care about anonymity and are only looking to help the network, add the following lines to bitcoin.conf:

There is also this guide https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/tor.md

It has some things in common with the first one. But in this one there is no reference to what is in the first one as method 2.

The method 1 is very similar to the method used by Jameson Lopp in here https://medium.com/@lopp/how-to-run-bitcoin-as-a-tor-hidden-service-on-ubuntu-cff52d543756


Now my next machine that I will call node 2 is a i7 machine with 32GB of ram, running Slackware Linux 14.2 64 bits.
I had this node running for long time because I use my armory wallet (watch only) on it.
But I tried the method 2 in https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Setting_up_a_Tor_hidden_service but as it says on

>If you care about anonymity, instead of the above, add the following lines to bitcoin.conf to use Tor for everything: 

This is node was this [`~/.bitcoin/bitcoin.conf`](https://pastebin.com/u5BFG92T)
I think that this problem is tor related so I tried to disable tor use on `~/.bitcoin/bitcoin.conf`
And this node shutdowns a few seconds after I do `bitcoind -daemon -disablewallet`

I changed lot of settings on the node started do shutdown to try to solve the problem.
I tried to make it connect t my node 1 with `addnode`  and because it didn't work I commented it out.

Then I commented out everything from the guide I followed on this setup (method 2 on the previous link).
And tried to force the node to not use tor with `listenonion=0`

This is the [`~/.bitcoin/debug.log`](https://pastebin.com/9pruNrWh)

**And now the weird part** , in this machine I have X so I can run bitcoin-qt and that work. The node start to sync and don't shutdowns. I run it at least for one hour before I disconnect it myself.
I want to run this node from terminal only.

And I have a third machine that I call node 3. And this machine is an RPi3 using an external hard drive to store the blockchain and runs Slackware ARM 14.2 current. This machine don't have X also.
I also think that this machine was a tor related problem.
I followed the same method and guide as node 2.

This is [`~/.bitcoin/bitcoin.conf`](https://pastebin.com/wXUR5LVv) and [`~/.bitcoin/debug.log`](https://pastebin.com/mAyCKkfR)

Like you can see it also shutdowns right away. This node intention is to only support the tor network because I run it like this `bitcoind -daemon -disablewallet`

And it follows the initial setup of node 2.

I am like this for two weeks and I don't know what to do...
I tried to comment settings and not use tor but I don't get nothing. The only thing I get is to sync my node 2 using bitcoin-qt. But without that node 2 don't run.
title: bitcoin node shutdowns right away
